The set ğ‘… of all images in the ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ -plane of all the points in a set ğ‘† in the ğ‘¢ğ‘£ - plane is called the image of ğ‘† under ğ‘‡. If distinct points in the ğ‘¢ğ‘£ - plane have distinct images in the ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ - plane, then ğ‘‡ is said to be one-to-one. Define a transformation from ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ - plane to the ğ‘¢ğ‘£ - plane that maps the image of (ğ‘¢, ğ‘£) under ğ‘‡ back to (ğ‘¢, ğ‘£). This transformation is denoted by ğ‘‡-1 and is called the inverse of ğ‘‡. There exist mathematical surfaces with only one side. This surface is called a MÂ¨obius strip. Calculus - MA2024 - 2022/2021 Batch - S3/S5 - University of Moratuwa Dr. Supem Samarasiri, Department of Mathematics, University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka Last updated: 08/29/2023 01:46AM Figure 6.5: MÂ¨obius Strip In applications, it is important to have some way of distinguishing between the two sides of an orientable surface. For this purpose let us suppose that Ïƒ is an orientable surface that has a unit normal vector n at each point. It can be proved that if Ïƒ is a smooth orientable surface, then it is always possible to choose the direction of n at each point so that ğ§ = ğ§(ğ‘¥, ğ‘¦, ğ‘§) varies continuously over the surface. These unit vectors are then said to form an orientation of the surface. Orientable Surface Definition 6.3.2: Orientation of a Smooth Parametric Surface When a surface is expressed parametrically, the parametric equations create a natural ori- entation of the surface. If a smooth parametric surface Ïƒ is given by the vector equation ğ« = ğ‘¥(ğ‘¢, ğ‘£)ğ¢ + ğ‘¦(ğ‘¢, ğ‘£)ğ£ + ğ‘§(ğ‘¢, ğ‘£)ğ¤ then the unit normal is a continuous vector-valued function of u and v. Thus, n defines an orientation of the surface; we call this positive orientation of the parametric surface and we say that n points in the positive direction from the surface. The orientation determined by -ğ§ is called the negative orientation of the surface and we say that -ğ§ points in the negative direction from the surface. Calculus - MA2024 - 2022/2021 Batch - S3/S5 - University of Moratuwa Dr. Supem Samarasiri, Department of Mathematics, University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka Last updated: 08/29/2023 01:46AM Definition 6.3.3: Flux The volume of fluid that passes through the surface in one unit of time. Here, we assume that fluid is in a steady state and is incompressible. The volume of the fluid that flows through a portion of the surface depends on three factors: 1. The speed of the fluid: the greater the speed, the greater the volume. 2. How the surface is oriented relative to the flow: the more nearly orthogonal the flow is to the surface, the greater the volume. 3. The area of the portion of the surface: the greater the area, the greater the volume. content: 8 Limits and Differentiation of Functions of a Complex Variable. 8.1 Functions of a Complex Variable Definition 8.1.1: Let ğ‘† be a set of complex numbers. title: 13. Residue Theory (ctd.)
content: 13 Residue Theory (Ctd....) 13.1 Evaluating Real Integrals through Residues Throughout the course I have mentioned the fact that line integrals over curves in 3-space and contour integrals on the complex plane can be converted to integrals over straight line segments on the real line using appropriate parametrizations.
